cluster_relations.rel_desc: Methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine are both used in amine treating to remove H2S and CO2 from hydrocarbon streams, indicating they serve similar functional roles and can be alternatives to each other.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ApplicationContext: amine treating of hydrocarbon streams for H2S and CO2 removal

remarks: Relation created to capture that these two amine treating chemicals share the same described use; semantics are approximated as an alternative/substitute relation since no explicit comparison wording is given.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is one of the four categories of stainless steels listed.
remarks: Although text just says 'duplex', entity is resolved as duplex stainless steel; relation captures the category membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is a subtype/category within the broader class of stainless steels.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities can be used in place of one another for the same functional role in a given application context.
args.justification: The relation describes methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine serving similar functional roles in amine treating and being usable as alternatives; a predicate emphasizing functional substitutability best captures this.
args.remark: Direction is arbitrary in this symmetric relation; canonical name is chosen to express functional interchangeability.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a broader class or category that includes the object as a more specific subtype or member category.
args.justification: Here, stainless steel is explicitly described as having duplex stainless steel as one of its categories; the direction is from broader class to included subtype, so 'has_subtype' is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype or category within the broader class represented by the object.
args.justification: This relation explicitly states that duplex stainless steel is within the broader class of stainless steel; with subject=duplex and object=stainless, the canonical predicate should be the subtype-to-supertype direction.

Both relations express hierarchical taxonomic links between material classes (stainless steel and duplex stainless steel), one from class to subtype and the other from subtype to class; they belong to the same material taxonomy family.

Taxonomic subclass/superclass relations between material categories express identity-like hierarchical classification, fitting an IDENTITY-style group (covering type-subtype and class-membership structures).
The relation captures that two chemicals serve the same function in a process and can substitute for each other, which is a functional equivalence/alternative family of relations.
The connection is about how the chemicals are used in the same application context (amine treating) rather than their composition or structure, so it best fits a broad USAGE-oriented group.
